reviews.text: It benefits from a fast pace and detailed animation.

While the youngest members of the household will enjoy a good dose of uplifting stories and fun for all audiences, adults will find a veiled sociopolitical backdrop, filled with class struggles and a robotic proletarian-Marxist revolution.

Uwe Boll could make a Transformers film for a buck fifty and employ only sock puppets and it would be praised to the high heavens simply for not being directed by Michael Bay. That’s the takeaway one gets after watching Bumblebee and now Transformers One.
Blessed with a strong, well-developed screenplay, the film boasts funny and engaging characters, inventive and eye-catching design, and tells a decent all-ages science fiction adventure.
It is a good starting place if you are either someone who's brand new to Transformers entirely or if you have seen other Transformers movies... this is a nice primer.
The market has been oversaturated with Transformers films for a number of years but Transformers One continues a trend of making a better prequel film.

... even as the script dips its toes into the expected, the ways in which it dispels audience pessimism through narrative turns and execution not only makes "One" entertaining, but makes it something worth revisiting.
the voice actors do a fine job of rendering the characters with humanity and empathy so that we have something genuine to hold onto even during all those metal-slamming fight scenes

Whether you're steeped in the lore, a fan of the live-action franchise, or a coming in with zero knowledge, Transformers One is a vivid adventure certain to capture - and keep - your attention until the credits roll.
I’m rolling with it.
The TRANSFORMERS franchise needed this film! A stunning animated origin story that showcases the beauty of friendship and the heartbreak of betrayal.
The film isn’t necessarily geared towards older fans of the Transformers brand but those willing to give it a shot will find a lot to love with Transformers One.
Featuring winning voice work from Hemsworth, Scarlett Johansson and Keegan-Michael Key, Transformers One brings welcome reserves of fun and character to otherwise over-familiar franchise material.
A refreshingly new breed of Autobot adventure -- one that has been notably souped-up in the brains department.

The screenplay from Eric Pearson, Andrew Barrer and Gabriel Ferrari is wildly ambitious, and includes the kind of next-level detail you wouldn't expect in a Spielbergian epic, let alone an angry android movie.
... An origin story that, if nothing else, is extremely loud.
Great animation, great plot, endless action and the voices bring the characters to life.

It's got lots of smashy-bashy action, satisfyingly crunchy silly machine Transformation, it's got a not-so-subtle message about power corrupting, and it's even got a couple of jokes that I actually laughed at.
Full of humour, adventure and heart, Transformers One is easily the most enjoyable entry in this long-running franchise, stripped of the excess and nonsense of the Bay era.
There are times when this feels more like a theme park ride than an engrossing narrative, but Transformers One is certainly a major improvement on Bay versions two, three, four or five.
What it doesn’t do is solve the problem of who the Transformers movies are actually for: nostalgic Gen-Xers or actual children.

Its problems, if any, lie within a fairly standard script that doesn’t completely branch out its intriguing ideas as much as it perhaps could have – but even with that being said, it’s still far beyond what has come before in this movie series.
A great big toy commercial masquerading as an entertainment.

…looks slick and expensive, and probably makes a bit more coherent sense than the live action versions, but the lack of public appreciation for Transformers One at the box office reflects how the fanboy tail is currently wagging the dog in 2024 cinema…
There’s actual character development, growth, story arcs, and dare I say humanity in this film about robots with morals and compassion.

Rather than forcing us to follow annoying humans or trying to innovate with strange changes to the lore, what the film does is deceptively simple: develop a narrative full of heart, centred on the beginnings of Optimus Prime. Full review in Spanish.
Transformers One does not belong to a franchise that could ever be accused of subtlety, but these stylistic choices make Josh Cooley’s film far more thoughtful and ingenious than the average reboot.

Engaging in a way the live-action offerings rarely are — and coherent in a way they almost never are — Transformers One serves up a fast-paced, humor-filled and untold origin of future rivals Optimus Prime and Megatron.
The whole thing has a visual style that feels original, and while the story hits familiar beats, it’s interesting enough that those beats feel fresh
Energetic and entertaining — and could have been even more, if the Paramount and Hasbro marketing departments hadn’t gotten in the way.

This film is the result of a franchise stretching its origins to keep itself alive. This prequel offers a lackluster take on how Optimus Prime rose to lead the Autobots. The film feels like a mass-produced toy—polished, predictable, and devoid of life.
It’s exciting, bold, thematically deep, and extraordinarily animated.
Transformers One is one of the best surprises of the year.
The action mattered, the character development was there, I like what they did with established characters... I really felt it was a prequel done right.
Transformers: One succeeds as a prequel because it cares about the characters at its heart.
Exciting and spellbindingly gorgeous, like a slick, well-tuned machine whose pieces slide and snap together with satisfying precision.

The prospect of another Transformers film might feel like one too many, but the animated Transformers One breaks some surprising new ground ... Who knew that watching Optimus Prime and Megatron before they were enemies could be so charming?
This is an unusually thrilling action movie that pulls the audience into a relentlessly entertaining romp. It also draws on classic movies for a remarkably complex view of heroes and villains.
At last, we have a Transformers movie set entirely on Cybertron, focused solely on the Transformers. And not only do we finally have it, but it’s also really good.

Visually, “Transformers One” delivers. It has high-end animation and a look that hardly screams Saturday morning television. The concept, however, still depends on your interest in a toy that starts as one thing and turns into another.
The film captures the spirit of the original television series, while embracing the improved animation technology that allows for larger and more intense action scenes.
For once they get a re-boot prequel right. Great characterisation that doesn't ruin the original source and just the right amount of comedy and action.
This Transformers is an artfully all-animated affair, and the switch to the illustrated realm is a winning one.
As expected, Transformers One is a true gift for fans of the franchise... [Full review in Spanish]

Excellent animation with witty dialogue and life lessons of what defines a transformer is not the cog in his chest but the spark in one's potential.  Great voice acting cast with hgihlights from Keegan Michael-Key and Scarlett Johansson

With top-notch production values, A-list voice actors, and a character-building story arc, Transformers One is occasionally predictable but still so much fun—even for those who aren't typically interested in the franchise.
The new animated Transformers One not only charts a path for sequels, it boasts enough inventive animation to push noise-weary watchers past its loud, repetitive battles.
Transformers One gets it right. It balances humor and more serious moments beautifully, there is plenty of incredibly effective action, and even the familiar voice cast isn’t distracting.
[A] lot of people are going to have a grand time watching Transformers One. Sadly, I am not one of them.
This animated prequel is a refreshing entry to the Transformers franchise.
Even its mistakes hardly qualify as mistakes, and the intelligence with which 'Transformers One' carries itself as an IP film easily cements it as an instant classic.

This animated feature continues on a trajectory that ignores Japanese contributions to the creation and popularity of Habro's Transformers toy line, despite attempts to bring diversity to the voice casting.

I don’t care how much the other movies have made, having a Transformers movie free of the chaos and beer-commercial filmmaking of Michael Bay is a breath of fresh air. Sure, it’s still noisy, cluttered and bombastic, but at least this movie is coherent.

So much to champion here, starting with director Josh Cooley's vision, to the groundbreaking animation, set designs add a new level of cinematic artistry to the franchise as the new look is stunning, not to mention realistic--the BEST film of them all!
Transformers One offers plenty to like but not much to love. The film takes the Transformers in a fresh direction while somehow still playing things too safe.
The fish-out-of-water storyline brings a refreshing change to the Transformers franchise, shifting the focus away from non-stop action and explosions.
Presented in the Michael Bay manner, with scenes so rapidly cut that you sometimes have to take the dialogue's word for what's happening onscreen. That said, it's a great-looking movie.
Combining a lively pace, striking visuals, scattered big laughs, and resilient and resourceful heroes, it's targeted primarily at kids but offers a nostalgic kick for an older generation, too.
Transformers One is convincing, fast-paced, layered, and a joy to keep up with.

This installment definitely benefits from the low expectations instilled by its predecessors, but that doesn’t take away from how its trio of writers create a consistently humorous script brimming with witty banter and quips that mostly land.

Transformers One combines the best animation that money can provide with a solid script and very solid voice performances from big-name talent, and just like that, it seems Transformers is back on track.
The best Transformers movie to date. Accesible to newcomers, while deep in lore for hardcore fans of the 40 year-old franchise, this new entry is a total blast. [Full review in Spanish]

Tthe film has something for first-timers and dedicated fans alike. It offers the perfect introduction to the world of Transformers. And thankfully avoids the bombastic approach of the Michael Bay films...watch it for its layered origin story...

It had to play to its emotional strengths and get us invested in the friendship that is the spark at the heart of this film, so that when the friends turn to enemies, it hits you hard. And in this one job, Transformers One succeeds.
I can’t think of a better way to describe this movie other than that this is more than meets the eye.

It exceeds expectations by deep diving into themes including loyalty, leadership, service, compassion, power, anger and forgiveness, all coated in breathtaking action animation, with a good dose of humor.
It's a great origin story for Megatron.
Cooley’s take on Megatron is way more intriguing and profoundly human, giving purpose to a character that has often been mistreated on film and television.
In the end, “Transformers One” has taken the heart (or Allspark) of the original animated offering and lifted it up because of first-rate visuals.
While just cutesy enough for the little ones and smart enough to pull in parents, this outing is more than meets the eye.
The rusted franchise gets reanimated, sparking some of the best buddy comedy banter, satisfying character arcs, and enough cheer-worthy moments to roll out immediately to see theatrically.

By making the shift from live-action to animation, the film is better able to channel a sense of imagination that was often lost amidst the ponderous narratives and chaotic action beats of the earlier films.

Knock me over with an iron feather, but this Transformers is a rousing adventure story with origin implications, jokes that actually work & a lively all-star cast. Going back to animation (for the 1st time since 1986!) was the best strategy for revival.
It’s so earnest, bringing notes of freshness and innocence to a prequel that, by all rights, shouldn’t have had any.
Visually spectacular, incredibly funny and filled with immersive action sequences - this film (apart from Bumblebee in 2018) has more heart than anything that's come before it.
A welcome new franchise has transformed from an old one.
The theme of tragic corruption makes for some of the best writing in any Transformers movie.
Director Josh Cooley gives Transformers One a surprising amount of dramatic heft, aided by Brian Tyree Henry’s fantastic performance.
Action packed and often funny and better than it has any business being, “Transformers One” should appeal to fans and newbies alike.
Best Transformers Movie Of All Time! Perfection!
An agile and entertaining movie, Transformers One revitalizes the mythology of these characters for a new generation. [Full review in Spanish]
For a familiar franchise, this feels like a new beginning.
I've been transformed into a fan thanks to well-designed action scenes, an origin story drawing from classic sources, and A-list actors bringing their A-game as voice talent.
... This movie is geared toward the new generation and has more in common with the original animated series. [Full review in Spanish]

Ultimately the film struggles to balance its various commitments, with a screenplay that never seems sure of whether it wants to be a pure comedy, a lore-packed adventure or a peppy children’s film that shuffles kids straight to the toy aisle.

I had a thought that seemed at once plausible and absurd. Taking in its landscape of moody pastel skies and jagged spears of metal and rock overgrown by vines and purple-pink moss, I wondered: Is this Transformers movie inspired by Andrei Tarkovsky?
Cooley’s film makes a good spinoff suddenly seem simple: Sometimes all you need is the imagination for heroes and villains, betrayal and glory — and heaps of plastic to smash together.
Runs like a well-oiled piece of “Transformers” machinery, but lacks the spark that would raise it beyond fan-friendly formula.

If you have seen Ben Hur and The Treasure of Sierra Madre and The Departed and The 10 Commandments and Star Wars and Planet of the Apes and The Matrix, you have a lot of what Transformers One brings together in your brain.
[T]he movie is ... familiar, narratively flat, and lacking in imagination.
No matter how much various filmmakers attempt to strip it back down from Bay-level bombast, Transformers can’t escape itself.
Transformers One is a standalone movie, one that offers up copious Easter Eggs for longtime fans, and a top-notch, entertaining entryway, with great characters and slick animation, for new fans.
It's a shiny, chaotic distraction that generates new marketing opportunities without any new artistic vision.
The animation in “Transformers One” is spectacular and lavishly detailed, and plummets us into a whole new, intriguing world.

“Transformers” will always be most beloved to Generation X as a cartoon series in the ‘80s, so it’s fitting that the franchise has literally gone back to the drawing board for one of its best efforts.
It is a strong origin story that also manages to present a society and a culture that develops as the adventure explodes. [Full review in Spanish]
For others less enthused, it’s exhausting. The machine doesn’t care. It just whams away. Implacable. Unstoppable. Unhuman.
The result is likeable enough to win over a whole new generation, starting the endless cycle of reboot and rebirth over again. Let’s roll?

Transformers One is an origin story, an adventure, the end of a friendship, and the beginning of a battle between transforming alien robots. It’s more than meets the eye; it’s not just mindless action—it’s a blast for the entire family.

The movie we fans have been waiting our entire lives; a perfect combination of heart, action, & humor. An animated adventure of cinematic wonderment, enriching the mythology, respecting the past while looking at the future. [Full review in Spanish]

Despite being a brand agnostic and not giving a darn about how Optimus and Megatron went from best buds to mortal enemies, I rather enjoyed Transformers One. It's a visually rousing, PLF-worthy sci-fi melodrama aimed at smart kids rather than dumb adults.
The movie aims to do justice to the source material with a more mature approach and a heart big enough to appeal to fans without falling into customary fan service. [Full review in Spanish]

“Transformers One” is a thoroughly enjoyable entry to the franchise. Its wonderfully executed origin parallel stories of self-discovery. It’s funny, filled with action, and one of the best-animated films of the year.
Wraps a solid "Baby's First Revolutionary-Schism" sci-fi/action story around a lot of striking animation and satisfying robot-punching adventure business.
It's solid, good, relatable...

With Toy Story 4's Josh Cooley coming over from Pixar to direct, you can see the influence on Transformers One. From the "child's toy" look of the Transformers to a very sophisticated and dramatic third act, this one might create a new generation of fans.
Transformers One is a lot of grandiose sci-fi fun.
Sadly, there’s not much more than meets the eye.

The writing team here isn’t above reciting the brand’s slogan to punctuate tropes. They fare better with the slapstick comedy -- how this movie makes pratfalls funny again is actually quite miraculous.
Transformers One isn't good enough to watch on a plane, even a trans-Pacific flight. The inflight map is better.
There is, in fact, more than…I expected, allowing Transformers One to deliver enough goods to go along with my questions concerning how an origin story works for robots.
While Transformers One does feel like a very well-animated Saturday morning cartoon, the plot is well thought out and the writing is smart and funny.

A great watch for longtime fans and their kids. Though the franchise’s box office success in this century has been predicated on noisy live action with a CGI assist, this exciting and fun-filled film returns the Transformers to their animated roots.
A usually dumbed-down franchise gets a jolt of intelligence and spirit in this solid animated entry.
An origin story told in an epic, deep and emotionally intense way. [Full review in Spanish]
Transformers One was surprisingly well done. It's now one of my favorite Transformers movies and is an entertaining adventure where we get to see the rise of Megatron and Optimus Prime.
Why weren't these films animated this whole time?
Transformers One combines humor and nostalgia to present the Autobot/Decepticon conflict in a fresh way that asks us to reexamine our thoughts about something we think we already know.

“Transformers One” is a classic class warfare, friendships, trust, loyalty and betrayal. More importantly, it's about the conscious choice each one makes. Fully animated, it's thrilling with high energy and heart, and may be the most human story of all.
A realm without physical limits is truly where the Transformers belong, but it doesn’t stop the film from delivering some surprising pathos while it’s there.

Transformers One brings the iconic transforming robots back to the big screen with vibrant animation and a compelling, biblical storyline focusing on the tragic friendship of the sentient beings destined to become Optimus Prime and Megatron.
Transformers One is the best Transformers ever! Grab the family, sit back, and enjoy the turbocharged thrill ride with explosive fun and plenty of heart.

Transformers One delivers all the elements I hoped for in a Transformers movie! It may start off a bit slow but quickly Transforms into one of the BEST in the entire franchise.  Definitely left like the X-Men First Class of the series.
I don't see how anyone can argue that it is not successful in being a Transformers origin story prequel. In fact, you can make an argument it is the best film the franchise has ever seen
A dull, tedious and ultimately exhausting animated action adventure with dazzling CGI. In a double feature with The Wild Robot, it would be the shallow and inferior B-movie.
It’s an origin story that’s fixated on doing something original with those origins, which pays off and shows that there is more than meets the eye to this franchise

The movie touches on several themes, like exploitation, corruption, and worker empowerment, in an engaging, entertaining, and fun way for the whole family. Viewers would be wrong to dismiss Transformers One as a “mindless’ cash-grab kids movie.

Transformers One excels, especially in the context of the previous Transformers film canon, in its exploration and definition of its characters, humanizing them and underscoring the tragedy that led former brothers-in-arms to become deadly enemies.

Those images of a younger Megatron and Optimus Prime fist bumping with the promise of having each other’s backs no matter what is the final knife in the chest as we all know what is to come for these former friends.

The story adds some nice twists to the Transformers’ mythos, and it will doubtlessly appeal to both longtime fans and their children. But while the film contains action and humor, it fails to seamlessly integrate its themes into the narrative.
It may be largely unoriginal, but it’s still a considerable amount of simple, clean fun.
Transformers One breathes new life into the Transformers franchise in the most superb ways, while keeping it rooted in the canon that’s so beloved by fans everywhere.

It’s doubtful anybody was losing any serious sleep over the origin story about how the Autobots and Decepticons came to be...yet the film does such a good job filling in the blanks to the backstory you might end up feeling guilty you didn’t care more.

Cooley is a little unsteady when juggling silliness and solemnity, but he scores with adventure, delivering appealing artistry and some operatic turns of plot as the characters return to their colorful, smash-em origins.
It takes a bit to really get going, but between the action scenes and the pathos, this is a hot rod with serious power under the hood.
There’s slightly more than meets the eye with Transformers One. While the art style is sometimes off-putting, its ideas are interesting enough to make it a decent addition to the franchise.

Transformers One is a mesmerizing CGI adventure chock-full of thrilling action scenes, great humor, and a thoughtful script with powerful themes. Raise your expectations, because Transformers One sets a new high standard for the long-running franchise.

The movie is unapologetically aimed at the children who have become an odd afterthought for this cinematic series so far and succeeds the most when not burdening itself with attempts to simultaneously satisfy the older fans.

Even if you don’t care two cans of WD-40 about the origin story... Its themes of friendship and underdog heroism, along with a visually impressive design and clean storytelling form a truly appealing film.
After decades of experience with the Transformers in various forms, I have come to the following conclusion: They make better toys than movies.
Transformers One is mostly content with half-hearted puns and barely legible Cybertronian battles that could have used some major transforming before rolling out.

WOW Transformers One is the BEST Transformers Movie!High Octane Action, Hilarious, & most importantly emotionally deep with its thematic on friendship + its layers on Social hierarchy brings to life some eye opening pieces to the Transformers Universe!
If this is the future of the Transformers franchise, then Autobot and Decepticons fans have a bright future to look forward to indeed.

For better or worse, Transformers One is for die-hard Transformers fans. This origin story has appealing visuals and action, but the plot might be too confusing for viewers who are new to the franchise.

Transformers ONE is the BIGGEST surprise of the year and exactly the SPARK the Transformers series needed. With stunning animation, hilarious moments, and a fresh take for all fans, it’s the best Transformers movie in years.

At its core, this is really a coming-of-age adventure story where the best friends turned sworn enemies go on a journey of self-discovery, and you best believe Transformers One is an adventure worth going on.
Fills in the backstory for the legendary “robots in disguise,” but there’s little here for viewers who come in with no investment in this universe, cinematic or otherwise.

Transformers One brims with energy, colour, humour and a surprising amount of metal-on-metal violence, and is at a scale that feels better suited to a show originally conceived as an elaborate toy commercial.

However rote the first act may be — and it is — the moment the lead robots gain the ability to transform and level up is calculated to kick your inner “OH MY GOD IT’S OPTIMUS PRIME I LOVE HIM!!!!” Into gear.
Transformers One easily wipes away the bad taste 20 years of live-action Transformers movies may have left for some. It’s big, it’s beautiful, and it’s arguably the best Transformers movie ever.
Transformers One channels the joy that first brought audiences to this universe back in the 1980s and proves there are still good stories left to tell.

Transformers One returns to the property’s purely animated roots. Yet, the story has more humanity than the films that co-star human actors, and ultimately makes you feel the operatic tragedy of Megatron.

Cooley crafted a beautiful visual experience that you can’t peel your eyes away from. Optimus Prime is the definition of inspirational, and Hemsworth delivered that message as he effortlessly embodied a leader.
Transformers One delivers some truly incredible action sequences, but most importantly it gives fans an origin story filled with heart and emotion.
Easily the best Transformers movie ever made

Director Josh Cooley and his collaborators clearly have a lot of affection for this world. The movie is visually creative and understands that, despite his toy origins, Optimus Prime has become an iconic character for a reason.

A fun reminder of why we all liked the robots who were more than meets the eye in the first place. It doesn’t touch the artistic crossover heights of Spider-Verse or Mutant Mayhem but that doesn’t mean it isn’t pretty darn great.

Transformers One shows how the franchise is served best in the cinema as animated feature films. Everything is cleaner and has better stories that feel made for a general audience of fans and newcomers.

To say Transformers One is a cut above most of its predecessors perhaps isn’t the wildest compliment, given the nadirs those blockbusting behemoths reached in the Michael Bay-directed era. But it earns that laurel regardless.

While still delivering the fun and excitement expected of Hasbro’s metamorphosizing robots, Transformers One approaches the well-known characters with a degree of nuance and complexity that marks the most sophisticated onscreen portrait of them to date.
It’s all executed competently but joylessly, with zero fun to be had as it labors across an hour and 40 minute runtime that feels both too short and painfully long.

Besides the raucous, de rigueur action sequences, Transformers One provides numerous witty jokes of both the verbal and visual variety and -- surprise, surprise -- genuine emotion. Consider this a franchise revitalized.

Transformers One is exactly what the franchise needs right now. Director Josh Cooley delivers a riveting original story told with great reverence and a level of maturity that will bring fans of all ages together.
Transformers One is the best Transformers movie ever made.
There’s a lot to love here — from the character dynamics to the thrilling action and gorgeous animation. It makes for an exciting origin story.
t's a fun, action-packed outing with surprisingly effective emotional resonance, adding layers to existing Transformers lore while being a worthwhile story in its own right.
"Transformers One" is the best movie in the "Transformers" franchise since the 1986 original.
The rarity of a franchise film that seems principally concerned with appealing to a new generation is more in line with the legacy of the original series than any film that has come since.
A visually stunning animated prequel with solid character arcs and thrilling action scenes.

synopsis: TRANSFORMERS ONE is the untold origin story of Optimus Prime and Megatron, better known as sworn enemies, but once were friends bonded like brothers who changed the fate of Cybertron forever.
